newsitem.title: UK: Four more Greenpeace protesters scale oil rig.
newsitem.headline: Four more Greenpeace protesters scale oil rig.

text.p: Four more Greenpeace protesters scaled a British Petroleum oil rig to join three other colleagues in an escalating bid to stop new oil exploration in the north Atlantic, Greenpeace said on Saturday.

It said the four used climbing equipment on Friday night to get up high into the eaves of the Stena Dee floating platform, which is headed for the Foinaven oil field about 100 miles north of Scotland.

The environmental protest group has also been blocking an Alantic Richfield Co rig off the Alaskan coast to keep it away from a field in the Arctic Beaufort Sea. But a U.S. federal judge on Friday ordered the activists to stay outside a moving safety buffer around the mobile rig.
The blockades, aimed at fighting global warming, are part of Greenpeace's most ambitious campaign yet against the oil industry.

The Stena Dee protesters have already spent six days in a survival capsule strapped to one of the legs of the oil platform. When the platform attempts to move, Greenpeace swimmers take to the water to try to block its path.
"Now we have seven campaigners in all on board the platform. We want to make it as difficult as possible for them to get us off," said Greenpeace spokeswoman Liz Pratt.
"If we burn all the known oil reserves in the world, there will be irreversible climate change," she said.
British Petroleum has served writs against the Greenpeace protesters, ordering them to stop their occupation of the Stena Dee.
But the group has said it will continue its protest until the oil company gives assurances that it will stop its developments in the Foinaven field.
